column3: No real expectations going in.  I found it much quieter than I had expected, and a lot of it more affordable than other big cities.  The amount of prepared food available, that was also delicious was stunning.
column9: The first quiet and orderly subway ride.
column18: Cabbage with vinegar needs to be made for tacos.
column19: Reasonably priced spa type experience, very chill.
column20: Our host said I looked like a Japanese wrestler, and it was a very warm and inviting evening,
column22: Food was unremarkable, but I enjoyed the beer.
column23: No, he doesn’t exist in Japan
column24: Watching a street full of people playing Pokémon go.

column23: Not really, I expected to see a lot more sonic and found very little.
column24: Triple at the Belgium Brewing Project, a few interesting beers at the YYZ Brewery.
column25: Hot Lemonade, White Grape soda, lactic acid soda
column26: I really enjoyed the throng of people leading up to the temple, the shops/market leading up to it, would have revisited with more time.  I enjoyed the spirituality of the people and the place, the smells of incense and whatever the shops had to offer.  It was an experience for the senses that I very much enjoyed.
column27: I stood out on the boat.  Standing outside in the middle of the Tokyo night was as quiet and serene as it gets in a fairly quiet and serene city,
column28: Beef Curry at the Sakura lounge.
column29: More junk food, more time sitting and people watching.  More time at the temple.  Some nature walks and some out of Tokyo experiences.  DisneySea.  All the food, all over again.
column30:
Beautiful city, lots of walking, lots of food and adult drinking.

The most memorable parts of the trip were the people, not the destinations.  Dave and Taz as our gracious hosts, Dave’s surrogate mother who looked at him with doting eyes relentlessly at the first restaurant, Dave’s friends who owned the restaurant and were so warm and welcoming, Ankhet’s (sp?) constant laughter.

Even our Aussie and New Zealander sumo wrestling  friends on the train were a joy.

The people of Japan as a whole were friendly and welcoming, perhaps sometimes disingenuous, but I never noticed.

column3: Thought my boots would be good for walking around. Too much walking, had to get different shoes.

column20: The food was as good as the friends were lovely, generous and kind. I hope to come back to palette someday.
